content: quote: Originally posted by skytail: americans, ) could you please help me to understand you better through music ? Can you post just 1 song, you wish me to hear? I will have em, write CD and will listen in my car remembering you i can start just the same thing in Russian internet communities. One song for the American ! Every Russian wish some song for you to listen. skytail, with all due respect, what are you trying to understand about Americans? If you are trying to formulate better relations bewteen Russian and America, then I applaud you for doing so. Personally, I've always been a fan of military marching music, from all over the world. Somewhere in my collection, I've got "Red Army Chorus on Parade." But I haven't listened to it in years. My guess is that the Russian Federation Army retained some of the old Soviet march songs, because some were traditional and not political. Many of these march songs were peformed by the Orchestra of the Regimental Garrison at Moscow, during the USSR period. Two that I recall from memory that I enjoyed, were "Meadowlands," and "March of the Don Cossacks." This message has been edited. Last edited by: ProgMod, Mon 30 March 2009 05:56 PM No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

I will have em, write CD and will listen in my car remembering you i can start just the same thing in Russian internet communities. One song for the American ! Every Russian wish some song for you to listen.
reply: skytail, with all due respect, what are you trying to understand about Americans? If you are trying to formulate better relations bewteen Russian and America, then I applaud you for doing so. Personally, I've always been a fan of military marching music, from all over the world. Somewhere in my collection, I've got "Red Army Chorus on Parade." But I haven't listened to it in years. My guess is that the Russian Federation Army retained some of the old Soviet march songs, because some were traditional and not political. Many of these march songs were peformed by the Orchestra of the Regimental Garrison at Moscow, during the USSR period. Two that I recall from memory that I enjoyed, were "Meadowlands," and "March of the Don Cossacks." This message has been edited. content: Skytail... Threerings is absolutely right. You want to know about America, then you got to listen to country music, jazz, or something contemporary. Hip hop and this techno-garbage is just ... el crapola. Hank Williams Jr., Springsteen, BB King, Charlie "Bird" Parker, just to name a few. Country music, jazz, and real rock n' roll are all American by birth. Harry Connick Jr., the Mills Brothers, and Frank Sinatra are other good ones who have an "American" soul to their music. I'm afraid one song just wouldn't do. You've got songs from New Orleans, to the Kentucky coal mines, to the Kansas City and Chicago jazz clubs. That's whats so incredible about this nation... you can drive 50 miles and find a completely different culture almost.
reply: Skytail... Threerings is absolutely right. You want to know about America, then you got to listen to country music, jazz, or something contemporary.
